Project Description  The Project for integrated flood protection covers nine secondary 
towns  in  Bangladesh:  Brahmanbaria,  Gaibandha,  Jamalpur, 
Kushtia,  Manikganj,  Munshiganj,  Mymensingh,  Rajshahi,  and 
Sunamganj. The selected towns are prone to river flooding, river 
erosion, waterlogging, and flash floods. The poorer income groups, 
especially  recently  settled  dwellers,  are  the  most  vulnerable  to 
disaster. Lack of flood protection and inadequate drainage lead to 
waterlogging  and  overflowing  of  sewerage  facilities,  especially 
latrines,  and  cause  widespread  environmental  degradation  and 
deplorable unsanitary living conditions.  
 
The  integrated  approach,  combining  river  protection  works  with 
drainage and basic sanitation services, is appropriate for the urban 
areas in Bangladesh, which are prone to frequent river flooding, 
particularly in low-lying areas with poor drainage systems. In the 
project  design,  flood  protection  works  are  fully  integrated  with 
drainage  system  improvement,  sanitation,  and  solid  waste 
management to establish better environmental conditions and more 
hygienic living conditions for the poor in the slums. 
 
While most of the project investments will be directed toward the 
construction of infrastructure facilities for urban flood protection, the 
participating  towns  will  also  implement  the  Urban  Governance 
Improvement  Action  Program  (UGIAP)  which  was  originally 
introduced in an earlier Asian Development Bank  (ADB)-assisted 
project in six key result areas,  four  for enhancing awareness and 
participation  of  local  stakeholders  in  urban  planning  and 
management,  and  two  for  improving  accountability  and 
transparency  in  municipal  administration.  The  long-term 
sustainability of the project investments will depend on progress 
that the project towns will make in managing their municipal affairs.

Rationale  The growth potential of the urban sector in Bangladesh is severely 
undermined by frequent flooding. There are about 550 urban centers 
in Bangladesh and many of them suffer from severe erosion and  
destruction of  physical infrastructure  caused by  river flooding  and  
waterlogging.  Flooding  is  a  perennial  problem  and the urban 
areas are more prone to economic and human losses due to their 
high population density and concentration   of   industrial   and   
investments  sites.    While  the Government had wanted to address 
the problems of flooding and erosion in urban areas as early as in 
the  1970s,  no  major  investments  could  be  carried  out  due  to 
resource constraints. As a result, the urban areas, especially the 
secondary towns, have remained neglected. 
 
After the devastating floods of 1987 and 1988, the Government and 
development partners prepared the Flood Action Plan. Under the 
plan, Dhaka and 15 district towns were identified for urban flood 
protection. ADB has already provided two loans to cover Dhaka and 
6 of the 15 district towns. ADB's intervention proved to be very 
effective, as evidenced during another massive flooding in 1998. The 
proposed Project will cover the remaining towns identified earlier. A 
feasibility study for a third loan for urban flood protection is included 
under the Project.  
   
Objectives   The Project comprises four components:   
(i)  Component A: flood protection works 
(ii)  Component B: urban drainage system improvement 
(iii)  Component C: urban environmental improvement  
(iv)  Component D: capacity building and implementation 
assistance 
 
Component A will consist of flood protection works for each of the 
selected towns. The works may be either new facilities or upgrade 
of existing ones. Typically, flood protection works include earthen 
flood  embankments,  reinforced  concrete  flood  walls,  drainage 
regulators, and river training or bank protection works including 
groynes and revetments. 
 
Component B will comprise improvements to the existing drainage 
works. The main works will be construction of large lined drains and 
open unlined drainage outfalls. Many small structures such as road 
culverts and bridges will be constructed throughout the drainage 
system. 
 
Based  on  the  very  positive  results  of  the  urban  environmental 
improvement works under the previous loan (particularly in slum 
areas),  greater  emphasis  in  the  second  phase  is  placed  on 
component C, which aims at environmental improvements at the 
town  level.  It  comprises  (i)  a  solid  waste  management 
subcomponent,  including  sanitary  landfill  sites  and  composting 
facilities;  (ii)  installation  of  sanitary  latrines;  and  (iii)  slum 
improvement activities. Road improvement works for small stretches

proposed administration by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) of a loan to be provided by the

2.  The  overall  project  framework  (Appendix  1)  summarizes  the  Project’s  objectives,

II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
 
1.  Urban Flood Protection in Bangladesh 
 
3.  Although  the  level  of  urbanization  in  Bangladesh  is  relatively  low  with  23%  of  the 
population residing in urban areas, already over 40% of the country’s gross domestic product 
(GDP)––from a low of 25% in the early 1970s––is derived from the urban sector. The role of the 
urban centers as the engine of growth is clearly recognized in the Government’s latest 5-year 
plan documents, which projected that the urban sector GDP would grow at more than twice the 
rate of the national GDP.  
 
4.  However, frequent flooding severely undermines the growth potential of the urban sector.   
There are about 550 urban centers in Bangladesh and many of them suffer from severe erosion 
and destruction of physical infrastructure because of river flooding and water-logging. Flooding is 
a perennial problem in Bangladesh and the urban areas are more prone to economic and human 
losses due to their high population density and concentration of industrial and investment sites. 
While the Government had wanted to address the  problems of flooding and erosion in urban 
areas as early as in the 1970s, no concerted major investments could be carried out due to 
resource constraints. As a result, the urban areas, especially the secondary towns, remained 
neglected.  ADB’s  country  strategy  and  program  for  Bangladesh  highlights  the  strategic 
importance of secondary towns in the urbanization process, and the need to promote them to 
lead a sound and balanced urban development. The Government's Interim-Poverty Reduction 
Strategy Paper (I-PRSP)1 also recognizes urban local bodies as one of the key instruments for 
ensuring improved quality and enhanced accountability of public service in urban areas. The I-
PRSP strongly supports capacity building at the local level, including effective participation of 
women in local governance. As for flood protection, reduction of vulnerability to natural disaster is 
recognized as an integral aspect of the national strategy for poverty reduction. 
 
5.  The devastating floods of 1987 and 1988 were a reminder to all concerned, including 
policy makers and external development partners, that the threats of severe flooding could no 
longer be left unattended (Appendix 2). A strong consensus was formed quickly for immediate 
action in a concerted manner. A year later, the Government and the international community 
together formulated a comprehensive program, called the Flood Action Plan (FAP), to develop a 
sustained solution to the dangers of frequent flooding. The FAP comprised 26 activities for 
physical investments, technical studies, and support activities. For urban flood protection, the 
FAP identified Dhaka and 15 district towns to be supported by the Asian Development Bank

6.  Prior to the ADB investments, the earlier interventions related to urban flood protection 
remained largely at master planning stage. Where actual investments were carried out, they were 
implemented by various agencies on an ad hoc basis without proper coordination. In fact, 
piecemeal efforts had generally been ineffective and, in some cases, inadvertently compounded 
the environmental health hazards. Inadequate drainage resulted in polluted waters remaining 
stagnant in low-lying land (often densely populated slum areas) for long periods. Uncoordinated 
collection and disposal of solid waste contributed to localized flooding due to clogged drains. 
Similarly, inadequate and ineffective excreta management led to high levels of exposure to 
waterborne pathogens during floods. A clear, urgent need thus emerged to integrate flood 
protection works with other infrastructure and environment improvement measures in selected 
high-priority secondary towns to maximize impact. Given such experience, ADB adopted an 
integrated approach where flood protection was combined with drainage, sanitation, solid waste 
management, and slum development in one project. 
 
7.  Although implementation of ADB’s integrated flood protection project for the six district 
towns was delayed by 2 years due to unforeseen natural causes and political events, flood 
protection facilities constructed under it have safely withstood annual flood seasons since then. 
Moreover,  monitoring  and  evaluation  (M&E)  reports  confirmed  that  the  total  beneficiaries 
exceeded the targets set during project appraisal. The respondents in both slum and non-slum 
areas cited significant direct benefits from reduced flood damage, including improved hygiene 
and a cleaner environment, and more efficient solid waste collection. Substantial indirect benefits 
were also reported: better housing, higher land values, increased daily incomes, and reduction in 
illness  and  medical  costs.  The  project  also  provided  significant  construction  employment 
opportunities for the local poor, and livelihood skills training for women-led community-based 
handicraft industries. With this positive feedback, the Government and ADB agreed to complete 
the flood protection facilities for the remaining nine towns that were left out from the first phase of 
the project. 
 
8.  However, since more than 10 years has passed from the selection of the original 15 
towns, it was necessary under the project preparatory technical assistance (TA) for the second 
phase to update flood information on the remaining towns and reassess the need for ADB 
support in those towns. The interministerial meeting held on 1 December 2003 reviewed the 
updated flood information and decided to include the following secondary towns in the second 
phase:  Brahmanbaria,  Gaibandha,  Jamalpur,  Kushtia,  Manikganj,  Munshiganj,  Mymensingh, 
Rajshahi City Corporation (RCC), and Sunamganj.

10.  The low-lying areas or in close proximity to the embankment, slum dwellers are the first to 
be inundated when the floods come, as those areas lack proper drainage and sewerage. When 
river erosion is severe, water intrudes into the surrounding areas causing severe waterlogging. In

11.  Often water is stagnant for 2-3 months. Inhabitants wade through knee- and waist-deep 
polluted water to go about their daily activities. Women and children suffer most. Young children 
who play in the polluted waters suffer from skin ailments and waterborne diseases. With little 
sanitation facilities in the best of times, during flooding and with mobility restricted even further, 
women  undergo  hardships  in  personal  hygiene  and  toilet  requirements.  With  no  sewerage 
facilities, overflowing of drains especially during the monsoons poses a health hazard. Lack of 
solid waste management is a constant threat to the environment. The economic activities of the 
poor are often jeopardized due to floods, when they remain busy in protecting their belongings at 
the cost of their employment. There is no ongoing flood or disaster preparedness program in the 
project towns. During the focus group discussions, women slum dwellers requested a special 
program  to  flood-proof  houses,  and  to  generate  income,  and  measures  to  ensure  normal 
movement year-round.   
 
B.  Analysis of Lessons Learned from Phase 1 
12.  The preparation of the phase 2 of the Project is firmly based on the lessons learned from 
phase 1.4 While many documents and reports have been prepared to fully or partially review the 
achievements of phase 1, project completion reports and the project performance audit report 
(PPAR)5 are particularly important. The project preparatory TA also carried out a separate review 
and consolidated all the lessons learned to incorporate them in the design of the new Project. 
While the Project is not perceived as disaster related, it has significant disaster mitigating 
implications. The Project will help reduce the incidence of future disaster related to flooding and 
lessen the demand for rehabilitation projects after disaster. As such, the design of the Project is in 
compliance with ADB’s Disaster and Emergency Assistance Policy, 2004.6  
 
13.  ADB’s PPAR by the Operations Evaluation Department confirms that phase 1 of the 
Project has achieved its main objective. Since project completion, the six towns have been 
protected from annual floods. Drainage and sanitation facilities have reduced the incidence of 
waterborne diseases. Improvements in the living environment as a consequence of the project 
were recognized by the majority of the respondents in all project towns. The slum improvement 
component directly benefited some 8,000 households and provided a greater sense of security 
and permanence within towns.      
 
14.  The PPAR pointed out, however, that adequate operation and maintenance (O&M) of the 
project assets is the main concern in the long term. It became evident that the project targets for 
revenue generation and O&M were too ambitious, while not much support was provided for 
capacity  building  in  financial  management.  Considerable  problems  also  persisted  with  the 
institutional and administrative capacity of the urban municipalities for effective provision of local

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
A.  Objectives 
 
16.  The Project will promote economic growth and reduce poverty in nine selected towns by 
providing a flood-free and secure living environment within the framework of integrated flood 
protection. The integrated approach, combining river protection works with drainage and basic 
municipal services, is appropriate for the urban areas in Bangladesh, which are prone to frequent 
river flooding, particularly in low-lying areas with poor drainage systems. The urban sector 
remains a priority for ADB because it presents a greater opportunity for both pro-poor economic 
growth, as well as targeted poverty reduction, particularly at the secondary towns level.  
 
17.  While the Project will benefit the entire urban community in the project towns, some 
components will focus on upgrading the conditions of the poorest and most needy groups in the 
slum  areas  in  particular.  Through  urban  governance  reforms  and  support  to  gender  and 
development activities, the Project will also promote active participation of women citizens in 
municipal management and services as both beneficiaries and agents. 
 
B.  Components and Outputs 
18.  The Project comprises four components:   
(i)  Component A: flood protection works; 
(ii)  Component B: urban drainage system improvement; 
(iii)  Component C: urban environmental improvement; and  
(iv)  Component D: capacity building and implementation assistance.  
 
19.  These four components are basically identical to those included in phase 1 of the Project. 
The lessons learned suggested that phase 2 should not depart from the previous project design 
but further strengthen the focus on environmental improvement activities, including solid waste 
management, low-cost sanitation, and urban poverty reduction. In the project design, flood 
protection works are fully integrated with drainage system improvement, sanitation, solid waste 
management, and slum improvement to establish better environmental conditions, including more

1.  Component A: Flood Protection Works 
 
20.  This component will consist of flood protection works for each of the selected towns. The 
works may be either new facilities or upgrade of existing ones. Typically, flood protection works 
include earthen flood embankments, reinforced concrete flood walls, drainage regulators, and 
river training or bank protection works including groynes and revetments.  
 
2.  Component B: Urban Drainage System Improvement 
 
21.  Component B will comprise improvements to the existing drainage works in each town. 
The  work  will  aim  to  reduce  nuisance  flooding  in  low-lying  urban  areas  and  improve 
environmental conditions generally by removing polluted storm water, which can be a health 
hazard as it is a source of waterborne diseases as well as a breeding ground for mosquitoes.  
 
22.  The main works require the construction of large lined drains and open unlined drainage 
outfalls. Many small structures such as road culverts and bridges are required throughout the 
drainage system. In addition, there is a demand for slabs to cover existing concrete drains, which 
are a safety hazard for small children and the elderly.      
 
3.  Component C: Urban Environmental Improvement 
 
23.  Based on the very positive results of the environmental improvements works under phase 
1 (particularly in slum areas), greater emphasis in phase 2 is placed on component C, which aims 
at environmental improvements at the secondary towns level. Component C comprises the 
following subcomponents: (i) solid waste management, (ii) sanitation improvement, and (iii) slum 
improvement. Road improvement works for small stretches connecting slums and solid waste 
disposal facilities are included in the respective subcomponents.  
 
24.  The solid waste management subcomponent will establish solid waste dump sites with 
adequate  controls  (including  sanitary  landfill  sites)  in  each  project  town  except  Manikganj; 
building a pilot composting facility in RCC; demolishing and disposing of dustheaps, improving 
collection facilities and establishing solid waste transfer stations, providing mechanical sweeping 
equipment for RCC on a pilot basis, and providing strainers for collecting solid waste from drains 
and transport, including rickshaws, pushcarts, garbage trucks, and bulldozers. 
 
25.  The sanitation improvement subcomponent will provide about 13,200 sanitary latrines and 
about 22 public toilets. In addition, unhygienic latrines will be converted into sanitary latrines.7

sustainability. Town authorities will engage sufficient manpower and water supply for cleaning 
public toilets several times a day. A sanitation management plan will be prepared for each of the

5.  Land Acquisition and Resettlement 
50.  The land acquisition and other resettlement impacts of the Project will not be significant 
despite the large number of affected persons (APs). According to the census undertaken during 
the TA, 10,228 persons will be affected by the Project; 8,443 by the river protection works and 
1,785 by the drainage improvement works. These are mainly informal dwellers who do not have 
any land titles to the property that they currently occupy. These people will need to move 
temporarily to allow construction to proceed, but they will stay close to the present locations and 
retain their existing sources of livelihood as well as social bonds. They will thus be saved from 
total disruption that is so common with relocation to distant locations.  
 
51.  The temporary removal of APs, however, will trigger resettlement safeguards. All APs are 
entitled to compensation packages elaborated in the entitlement matrix of the resettlement plan 
summary10 (Appendix 10). During socioeconomic surveys and a census of all potentially affected 
communities, APs expressed their willingness to self-relocate. The Project will assist them when 
they relocate as stated in the resettlement plan. The plan was disclosed to all APs during 
stakeholder consultations and will be posted in BWDB, LGED and ADB web sites. The Project 
will not have any  impacts on indigenous people since there are no indigenous people in the 
project towns. 
 
6.  Solid Waste Management Activities 
52.  To  prevent  unhygienic  conditions  currently  faced  in  most  cities,  dustheaps  will  be 
demolished and CBOs and NGOs will implement door-to-door collection of solid waste. New or 
improved facilities for solid waste collection will be provided. Waste segregation will take place 
mostly at the collection stage. Garbage trucks will park at transfer stations on schedule, liaise with 
solid waste collection facilities, and transport waste to solid waste dump sites with adequate 
environmental  controls  or  sanitary  landfill  sites.  These  sites  will  be  provided  with  suitable 
impervious lining, and leachate collection will take place in purposely built, lined leachate ponds. 
Leachate tanks will be provided to allow for leachate decay before arranging for final safe 
disposal. It is proposed that the entire solid waste management cycle (collection, transportation, 
segregation,  reuse,  disposal,  and, where relevant, recycling) be operated through either (i) 
partnerships where the municipalities own the facilities and CBOs operate them, or (ii) micro 
enterprises where CBOs both own and operate solid waste management services. The issue will 
be explored in the solid waste management plans to be formulated for each project town. Public 
awareness and capacity to operate such schemes will be provided by the UMSU.

64.  The PMOs will receive monthly and quarterly progress reports from all PIUs under their 
jurisdiction. The PMOs will consolidate those reports into one report to be submitted to ADB and

10.  Project Performance Monitoring and Evaluation 
65.  The performance evaluation and monitoring of the Project will be carried out under the 
direction of the PMT and following ADB’s guidelines for this purpose. With the assistance of the 
consultants, BWDB and LGED will establish a management system to ensure that the facilities 
are managed efficiently and the expected benefits are maximized. M&E will determine the 
effectiveness of the integrated flood protection measures introduced under the Project and the 
improvements on public health, environment, property values, and operational efficiencies that 
have taken place.  
 
66.  To ensure that project activities and facilities are managed efficiently and that benefits 
reach the target groups, an M&E program will be included the framework of ADB’s project 
performance monitoring system (PPMS). PPMS activities will be conducted periodically to gather 
information through multiple sources to determine whether the input deliveries for implementing 
program activities have rendered the expected benefits to the intended beneficiaries. The PPMS 
also seeks to detect any deficiency and discrepancy between the plan and the execution of a 
program in using the resources efficiently so that timely corrections can be made to update the 
program and thus improve the benefits, outcomes, and impact. The indicators to be monitored will 
be formulated and agreed upon with BWDB and LGED and will include indicators pertaining to 
both physical progress and capacity building activities. The PMOs will conduct initial baseline 
physical and socioeconomic surveys and submit a detailed implementation plan for monitoring 
performance and for preparing benchmark information for ADB’s review and concurrence within 6 
months  of  loan  effectiveness.  Thereafter,  PMOs  will  submit  annual  M&E  reports  to  ADB 
throughout Project implementation.

67.  ADB and the OPEC Fund will conduct detailed reviews of the Project at least twice a year.

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
 
A.  Major Benefits and Impacts 
 
1.  Social and Gender Aspects 
 
68.  Poverty incidence was as high as 40% of the sample households, where income is below 
the poverty line of Tk44,410 per year ($65 per month). Households in hard core poverty survive 
on incomes of less than Tk36,345 per year ($53 per month), concentrate in overcrowded slum 
and  squatter  areas,  and  lead  a  hand-to-mouth  existence.  Between  7%  and  30%  of  the 
households in hard core poverty are headed by women (Appendix 11). Focus group discussions 
strongly underline the appeal of the poor for employment opportunities and decent wages; their 
emphasis is on the need to improve drainage for quicker clearance of rainwater and facilitation of 
normal movement during flooding to mitigate the loss of workdays. Women are particularly 
concerned about shelter for themselves and their animals, children’s access to schools, as well 
as access to medicine and health care, especially during floods. Poverty reduction has been 
made as a strategic objective of each Project component, with the view to maximize employment 
during construction, develop skills for O&M, and make roads and basic services available in 
deprived areas. In slums, improved access to water supply, sanitation, solid waste disposal, 
roads and footpaths, lighting, schools and health care will be assured. To this end each town will 
have its own PRAP and GAP, which will be prepared with primary stakeholder participation, in 
response to expressed needs.12 
 
2.  Economic and Financial Feasibility 
69.  The  economic  analysis  confirms  substantial  economic  benefits  from  the  project 
components in all nine project towns. The main economic benefits include (i) flood damage 
mitigation for buildings and all types of property, (ii) mitigation of infrastructure damage, (iii) 
enhancement of land values, and (iv) enhancement of economic activities. While the Project will 
mainly address urban flood protection within municipal boundaries, proposed works will provide 
significant peripheral benefits to cultivated land outside the town boundaries. While improved 
sanitary conditions through solid waste management and installation of sanitary latrines will bring 
numerous health benefits, these are not quantified. The economic internal rate of return (EIRR)

calculated for all project towns, ranges from 13.5% in Rajshahi to 44.6% in Jamalpur. The EIRR 
for the Project as a whole is estimated at 22.8% (Appendix 12) The overall poverty impact ratio is 
estimated to be 48%. 
 
70.  The financial base of the project towns is weak, with per capita revenues averaging Tk413 
($7.0) per year. Own-source revenues make up one half of total revenues, with the balance 
received as municipal grants from the Government. Since the project capital costs (drainage, 
solid waste, sanitation, slum improvement) are financed by Government grants, the cost recovery 
strategy under the Project is aimed at meeting the incremental O&M costs through increased 
revenue mobilization, the success of which relies heavily on efficient property tax collection. 
Based  on  the  lessons  learned  from  phase  1,  institutionalized  training  will  be  provided  by 
implementing  the  UGIAP  to  improve  financial  management  in  the  project  towns.  Proposed 
property tax reforms include raising the tax collection efficiency from the current average of 52% 
to 80% and above, and regularly updating property assessments (analysis of municipal finance is 
summarized in Appendix 13).  
 
3.  Environmental Aspects 
71.  The Project has been classified in environmental category B.  As part of the project 
preparatory  TA,  initial  environmental  examinations  (IEEs)  were  carried  out  for  all  project 
subcomponents. The IEEs showed that none of the proposed components would have significant 
adverse  environmental  impacts.  The  summary  IEE  is  in  Appendix  14.13 Anticipated  minor 
environmental  impacts  include  generation  of  dust  and  air  pollution  due  to  demolition  and 
excavation  activities,  and  increased  vibrations  and  noise  during  construction;  increases  in 
exhaust fumes and traffic during construction activities and transport of solid waste to dump sites; 
and hygiene and sanitation problems arising from inappropriate O&M of latrines and solid waste 
dump sites.   
 
72.  Environmental benefits resulting from the Project include improved hygiene and sanitary 
conditions and improved waste handling, treatment and disposal. To guide these activities, a solid 
waste management plan and a sanitation management plan will be formulated before loan 
effectiveness. The two plans will include public awareness as well as models for operationalizing 
and maintaining latrines and solid waste management facilities, including sanitary landfill sites 
and composting facilities. The riverbank will have significant positive impacts by protecting the 
productive agricultural and homestead land from progressive river erosion.  
 
B.  Major Risks 
73.  While no unusual risk is foreseen during implementation, the potential risks concern (i) 
implementation delays due to slow progress with start-up activities (such as engagement of 
consultants and completion of administrative changes required for launching regional training 
centers), (ii) lack of suitably qualified personnel in the project towns that may eventually lead to 
weak implementation of the subproject at the town level, (iii) inadequate coordination between 
BWDB and LGED, (iv) unavailability of the OPEC Fund cofinancing, and (v) sustainability of the 
facilities and services provided under the Project. 
 
74.  First, implementation delay can largely be prevented by timely mobilization of consultants. 
Advance action is required to ensure that the implementation schedule can be adhered to. 
Second, the Government will ensure that qualified staff in the PIU are nominated and provided 
with advance training before loan effectiveness. Third, the two PMOs will be set up and placed in

75.  Finally, the sustainability of the project investments will depend primarily on the ability of

A.  Specific Assurances 
76.  In  addition  to  the  standard  assurances,  the  Government  has  given  the  following 
assurances, which are incorporated in the legal documents: 
 
(i)  Within 3 months of loan effectiveness, each project town will have entered into a 
formal agreement with LGED for the effective implementation of the UGIAP for that 
town. The Government will ensure implementation of the UGIAPs in accordance 
with  the  set  time  frames.  The  formal  agreement  with  LGED  for  UGIAP 
implementation is a condition for awarding civil work contracts for the project 
towns. 
(ii)  The Government will cause BWDB and LGED to adopt the GAP and PRAP and 
will ensure their full implementation throughout the project period. To this end, the 
Government will require the PMOs to prepare field manuals for the GAP and 
PRAP and conduct training for the PMO and PIU staff. Implementation of the GAP 
and PRAP will be closely monitored and progress will be described in the quarterly 
reports to ADB.

construction, the work plans and preliminary designs will be presented to the 
beneficiaries at a town meeting organized by the town chairperson (or mayor of

beneficiaries in a manner that ensures they gain a full understanding of the 
proposed  works.  The  presentations  will  actively  involve  suitable  engineering 
project personnel from BWDB and LGED (depending on the work component 
involved) and the towns (or RCC), as well as the MDS consultant. Approval in 
principle for the works to proceed must be sought. 
(iv)  BWDB and the project towns will complete detailed surveys and prepare detailed 
land acquisition plans each year for the works to be undertaken during the coming 
fiscal year and submit them to the deputy commissioner of the respective towns at 
the latest 3 months before the working season so as to complete all formalities as 
well as physical land possession before the working season begins.

THE WATER SECTOR IN BANGLADESH 
 
A.  Institutional Development 
 
1.  After the creation of Pakistan in 1947, the provincial Irrigation Directorate was in charge 
of the development of water resources and flood control facilities. Following the devastating 
floods of 1954 and 1955, a United Nation (UN) mission—the Krug Mission— recommended the 
creation of the East Pakistan Water and Power Development Authority (EPWAPDA). This was 
established  in  1959  with  two  wings:  Water  Wing  and  Power  Wing.  The  Water  Wing  was 
restructured in 1972 as Bangladesh Water Development Board (BWDB) and its mandate limited 
to water resources development. BWDB was reconstituted in July 2000 under a new Act that 
repositions the organization and aligns its responsibilities to those set out in the National Water 
Policy (NWP).   
 
B.  Milestone Events in the Water Sector 
 
2.  The Water Wing of EPWAPDA prepared a master plan envisaging 58 massive flood 
control  and  drainage  (FCD)  projects  and  three  barrages  on  three  major  rivers.  Projects 
implemented by EPWAPDA covered mainly the engineering aspects to help boost agricultural 
production to meet the country’s demand. It was claimed that the master plan ignored the needs 
of nonagricultural water-using sectors. A World Bank study in 1972 suggested a major shift in 
strategy from massive FCD projects to minor irrigation complemented by agricultural input supply 
and support services. The World Bank Mission recommended a review of BWDB activities and 
stressed the creation of a planning body outside BWDB to prepare a NWP that emphasizes on 
maximizing agricultural growth and production for food grain self-sufficiency. The NWP that was 
prepared put heavy reliance on minor irrigation through massive fielding of tube wells and low-lift 
pumps utilizing available surface water from rivers and other water resources. 
 
3.  The country experienced two consecutive massive floods in 1987 and 1988, which 
prompted the government to undertake immediate rehabilitation works, and in parallel a few joint 
studies.  Later  a  flood  action  plan  (FAP)  consisting  of  26  studies  and  pilot  projects  was 
undertaken with the support  of various sources. The major achievement of the FAP was the 
preparation of five regional studies and three important guidelines for: (i) project assessment, (ii) 
people’s participation, and (iii) environmental impact assessment. At the conclusion of the FAP 
studies the Bangladesh flood and management strategy was produced as the final report of the 
FAP. The report outlined a strategic framework for developing and implementing a national water 
management system and formulating a NWP and national water management plan (NWMP). It is 
worth mentioning that the NWP was prepared and approved by the Government in 1999, while 
the NWMP was approved by the Government on 31 March 2004. The Secondary Towns 
Integrated Flood Protection Project-II (STIFPP-II) is being formulated under the umbrella of the 
FAP. The NWMP provides the overall approach to and program for future urban flood protection, 
but actual formulation of the investment plans will be the responsibility of the end users. 
 
4.  The FAP was instrumental in bringing a paradigm shift in water planning methodology, 
putting emphasis on equal rights of all water users and mandatory use of environment impact 
assessment (EIA) and guidelines for people's participation at all stages of the project cycle 
(planning, design, implementation, and operation and maintenance). In line with the above 
policies and with the changing demand, the role of BWDB has been redefined and a new 
management structure is in place through reforms and downsizing of its manpower.

C.  Key Issues 
 
5.  Bangladesh is making good progress in establishing an up-to-date and comprehensive 
legal,  policy,  planning,  institutional  framework  for  the  water  sector.  Some  elements  of  the 
framework are NWP, MWMP, and reforms in the key institutions responsible for water resources 
management. A milestone in formulating policy and planning for the sector was the adoption of 
the  NWP  in  1999,  a  step  further  toward  good  governance.  The  NWP  also  defined  major 
institutional reforms, and the role of the government, the private sector, and civil society in water 
management. The NWP has called for accelerating the development of sustainable public and 
private water delivery systems with appropriate legal and financial measures and incentives 
including  formulation  of  water  rights  and  water  pricing.  The  NWP  has  also  called  for 
decentralization of water management. A scheme of up to 1,000 ha command area is to be given 
to the local government to plan, execute, and operate. 
 
6.  As dictated by the NWP, the government revised the earlier guidelines for people’s 
participation and replaced it with Guidelines for Participatory Water Management. The guidelines 
incorporate the mechanism for establishing and operationalizing beneficiary organizations like 
water user associations and linking with state institutions. In line with the NWP, the NWMP was 
approved by the Government on 31 March 2004. Even before approval, the salient features of 
the NWMP were incorporated in the Government's Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper.  
 
7.  The institutional reforms currently on the agenda are based on the NWP. Key BWDB 
reforms include redefining of BWDB’s role in the sector, changing BWDB's management to make 
it fully autonomous with an independent governing council, separating management from the 
governing council, and reducing the permanent staff from 18,000 to 8,860 by June 2007. Overall 
progress in reforming BWDB has been substantial. Given the accomplishment of the past years, 
it is possible that most of the actions associated with the reform process will have been 
addressed by 2007. The BWDB Act has mandated participatory management of projects. The 
objective is to promote a sense of ownership among beneficiaries and their willingness to share 
the cost of maintenance that would eventually relieve BWDB of the O&M burden. Progress is 
slow on this. 
 
8.  River training and bank protection works by BWDB have been found very costly, but they 
have been the only effective means of combating river erosion. Erosion control schemes show 
that they involve high maintenance expenditure, but they can provide protection. There is a need 
for contingency planning to cope with failure, and beneficiary participation in erosion control 
programs has proved extremely useful.

Despite the high incidence of natural disasters and many adverse conditions, Bangladesh has achieved considerable 
progress over the years in reducing both income and human poverty. Absolute poverty dropped from 58.7% in 1991 to

from 44.9% (1991) to 36.6% (2000). Whereas progress in reducing the head count index of poverty was better in the 
urban areas, rural areas fared better in reducing the severity of poverty as captured by trends in poverty gap and 
squared poverty gap. The uneven reduction in urban poverty is explained by the greater urban income inequality, as 
the Gini coefficient increased by 2.3% per year, from 0.307 to 0.368 over the period.  
 
The principal reason behind this phenomenon is the steady migration of the resource poor from rural to urban areas in 
search of employment and better economic opportunities. Migration inflates the annual growth rate of the urban 
population and triggers the sprouting shanty settlements along the towns’ river embankments or in surrounding low-
lying areas. In some towns considered under Secondary Towns Integrated Flood Protection Phase II (STIFPP-II), 
such settlements represent more than 25% of the population. The towns are prone to flooding and river erosion, and 
the poorer income groups, especially recently settled women dwellers, are very vulnerable to disaster. Lack of flood 
protection  and  inadequate  drainage  lead  to  waterlogging  and  overflowing  of  sewers,  causing  widespread 
environmental degradation and deplorable unsanitary living conditions, particularly in slums and squatter areas.   
 
Urban development is important in reducing the vulnerability of the urban poor and contributes to a safer, less morbid 
living environment for them throughout the year. The provision of flood protection infrastructure, drainage, slum 
improvement, and capacity assistance for improving urban governance will enable the poorer groups, men and 
women, to benefit directly from employment created in construction and operation and maintenance (O&M), and from 
additional social programming around microcredit, income generation, and environmental improvement, all of which 
are indispensable to reduce poverty. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has already lent well over $300 million for 
six urban infrastructure projects since it began its operation in Bangladesh in the late 1980s. The proposed 
intervention will significantly enhance the gains made so far in urban infrastructure and governance and in reducing 
poverty in the secondary towns of Bangladesh.

Asian Development Bank (ADB) Framework for the Economic and Financial Appraisal of Urban 
Development  Sector  Projects  and  Guidelines  for  the  Economic  Analysis  of  Projects.  The 
analysis draws on the socioeconomic survey and flood damage assessment survey carried out 
under the project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) and other available secondary data. 
The basic assumptions follows: (i) capital and operation and maintenance (O&M) costs were 
apportioned into traded and nontraded components and labor; (ii) using the domestic price 
numeraire, financial prices based on June 2004 prices and reduced by duties and taxes were 
converted to economic prices by a shadow exchange rate factor of 1.1 for the traded-cost 
component and 1.0 for the nontraded-cost component; (iii) a conversion factor of 0.9 was used 
for the cost of unskilled labor and 0.85 for skilled labor to reflect the real market value of labor, 
which is lower than the official wage rates used in the financial cost estimates; (iv) a subproject 
component was assumed to have a useful economic life of 30 years after construction; and (v) 
the  real  opportunity  cost  of  capital  employed  in  the  analysis  was  assumed  at  12%,  and 
represents the social opportunity cost of capital (SOCC) for Bangladesh. 
 
2.  Least-cost analysis compares alternative options for supplying the same output to meet 
the projected demand. Under the Project, however, no other option is considered for the 
following reasons. First, the project design is based on the lessons learned from phase 1 that 
was rated as successful. While adjustments are made to reflect the lessons learned, the 
technical solutions under the Project generally employ the same methodologies as those in the 
previous  loan.  Second,  the  project  design  standard  follows  the  requirements  of  the 
Government's policy on water resources management. 
 
B.  Economic Benefits and Valuation  
 
3.  The benefits considered in the economic analysis are (i) flood damage mitigation for 
buildings and different types of property, (ii) flood damage mitigation for municipal infrastructure 
facilities, (iii) flood damage mitigation for cultivated land, (iv) increase in land values, and (v) 
enhanced economic activities. The methodology used in determining the benefits is as follows.

income in the case of crop damage.

4.  Land Value Increases 
 
8.  Significant increase in land values is expected. Land value increases, estimated at 8%

An attempt was made to identify the multiplier effects on major items, such as consumer 
products, building and petroleum products, and the demand that might arise from the project 
works. The resultant demand is multiplied by current prices to determine revenues.

D.  Poverty Reduction Impact 
 
13.  The  poverty-reducing  impact  of  the  Project  is  traced  by  evaluating  the  expected 
distribution of net economic benefits to various groups.  A poverty impact ratio expressing the 
proportion  of  net  economic  benefits  accruing  to  the  poor  is  calculated  by  comparing  net 
economic benefits to the poor with net economic benefits to the project as a whole. 
 
14.  The portion of the four groups (consumers, government, private sector and labor and 
beneficiaries) that were classified as poor was assessed.  For consumers, the town profiles 
represent an analysis of the distribution of household incomes across a range of monthly 
incomes. The bottom two groups classified as “poor” and “very poor” were taken as being 
representative of the poor in that particular town. Government represents the economic effect 
on the economy as a whole. The poor of the country will share, probably disproportionately, in 
any increase or decrease in the gross national product of the country. In Bangladesh, the 
resultant share of the poor in incremental increase or decrease in gross domestic product 
(GDP) is calculated at 18%. Although it is inevitable that the poor will share in net economic 
benefits to the private sector, it is assumed that the poor will not share in any benefits allocated 
to the private sector.  On the other hand, all net economic benefits allocated to labor and 
beneficiaries are assumed to reach the poor. The overall poverty impact ratio is estimated to be 
48%.

FINANCIAL ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The financial analysis focuses on cost recovery measures that the municipalities must 
take  to  ensure  that  they  will  be  able  to  finance  the  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M) 
expenditures associated with local components of the project (drainage, solid waste, sanitation, 
slum improvement). Project capital costs as well as the O&M costs for the flood protection 
works are financed centrally by the Government and therefore will not burden the municipal 
budgets.  
 
B.  Financial Management 
 
2.  Accounting  and  financial  management  of  the  municipalities  are  governed  by  the 
Pourashavas Ordinance of 1977. Municipalities follow the government system of accounting, 
which is cash-based financial reporting rather than accrual-based accounting procedures. The 
assets and liabilities are not accounted for and information on the true cost of providing urban 
services is not determined precisely. The Government is currently considering a revision of the 
1985 Model Tax Rule which on implementation will substantially increase municipal income 
from sources other than the property tax.  
 
3.  As the Project calls for large investments that will have a major impact on cash flows, it 
requires the project municipalities to follow a more organized approach in managing financial 
resources. Most of these municipalities are financially weak. Tax collection efficiency is far from 
satisfactory, annual development grants are used to finance current revenue expenditure, Tax 
arrears are increasing, and power bills remain unpaid. Thus, project municipalities have to move 
now toward improved efficiency and additional resource mobilization, not only to meet the 
current  deficit  but  also  to  meet  the  additional  costs  to  operate  and  maintain  the  project 
components.  
 
4.  Following the lessons learned from phase 1 of the Project, institutionalized training to 
improve  the  financial  management  of  the  project  towns  will  be  provided  through  the 
implementation of the Urban Governance and Improvement Action Program (UGIAP). The 
Project  municipalities  will  be  required  to  adopt  a  time-bound  financial  accountability  and 
sustainability action program suggested in the UGIAP. 
 
C.  Municipal Revenue and Expenditure 
 
5.  The main sources of municipal revenue are property taxes; business taxes such as trade 
licenses, vehicle fees, ferry ghat charges, and user charge where a service is provided; bazaar 
and other property rentals;  and other miscellaneous revenues. In addition, The Government 
provides a revenue grant, which includes a grant for salaries and a general grant to compensate 
for  the  loss  of  revenue  from  octroi,  and  a  development  fund  grant  for  construction  and 
maintenance of infrastructure under the Government's annual development program (ADP).    
 
6.  Aggregate annual revenues in the project municipalities are $8.5 million. The average 
annual revenue is $0.95 million. The maximum and minimum revenues are $5.3 million and 
$0.27 million, respectively. Own-source revenues make up one half of total revenues, with the

F.  Cost Recovery 
 
13.  The rates and charges currently used by municipalities for cost recovery are not all 
necessarily  appropriate  funding  mechanisms  for  recovery  of  incremental  O&M  costs.  The 
drainage improvements and solid waste management services confer a specific benefit to 
individual property owners as well as a general benefit to all community members within the 
municipal boundaries. The property tax is a broadly based local tax that allocates cost to tax 
payers in proportion to assessed property values. For this reason, the property tax is the best 
funding instrument for drainage maintenance and solid waste management services.  
 
14.  The first step toward cost recovery is tax reform involving an increase in collection 
efficiency and property assessments. Efforts to update assessments and improve tax collection 
should be pursued first to realize the full potential of existing property taxes. These efforts will 
also reduce the implicit cross subsidy that now exists between people who pay their taxes and 
those who do not. With adequate promotion, this change can increase public acceptance of the 
property tax system and public willingness to accept future tax rate increases. The following 
measures are proposed as a cost recovery strategy for municipal O&M costs: 
(i)  Improve property tax collection efficiency and update property assessments. An 
overall  collection  efficiency  of  80%  and  a  20%  increase  in  assessment  are 
proposed as achievable targets by FY2009. 
(ii)  Increase property tax rates as needed up to the maximum allowable thresholds to 
cover the remaining funding deficits by FY2009.  
(iii)  Increase  other  user  fees  and  charges  as  a  last  resort  if  property  tax  rate 
adjustments do not generate sufficient revenue. 
 
15.  A specific charge for solid waste collection from individual households is an appropriate 
user fee. Such fees are currently used at a neighborhood level in Bangladesh municipalities to 
finance waste collection services organized by community groups. This funding arrangement 
has the added advantages of conferring direct local control on the delivery of the service, 
creating employment opportunities for low-income households, and providing market-based 
incentives to encourage efficient service delivery. Project municipalities  will therefore aim to 
fund the solid waste management services in a similar manner without direct financial or 
operational involvement.

OM Section F1/OP. Subcomponents to be financed under the Project showed no significant 
environmental  impacts.  Project  activities  that  may  have  a  marginal  effect  and  the  main 
mitigating measures proposed are summarized here. Overall the project is expected to result in 
substantial  environmental  benefits.  The  IEE  is  in  agreement  with  ADB’s  Environmental 
Guidelines  (2003)  and  Bangladesh’s  laws  and  regulations,  including  Bangladesh’s  EIA 
Guidelines (1997). 
 
2.  The Project aims to provide a flood-free and more secure living environment in nine of 
Bangladesh’s secondary towns through flood protection, improved internal town drainage, urban 
environmental improvements, solid waste disposal, improved sanitation, capacity building, and 
implementation assistance. 
 
B.   Description of Project Components 
 
3.  The main components to be financed by ADB are (i) flood protection works, (ii) drainage 
system improvements, (iii) urban environmental improvements, and (iv) capacity building and 
institutional strengthening.  
 
4.  The  flood  protection  works  component  comprises  new  schemes  for  the  towns  of 
Brahmanbaria, Jamalpur, Manikganj, Mymensingh, and Sunamanj where embankments that will 
effectively  convert  them  into  polders  will  surround  the  last  two.  Gaibandha,  Kushtia,  and 
Rajshahi will require extension and rehabilitation works. Flood protection works typically include 
building  and  repair  of  flood  walls  (approx.  20  kilometers  [km]);  resection,  rehabilitate,  or 
construct core wall embankments (approx. 70 km); regulators and pipe sluices (approx. 90); 
revetment works, groynes, and spurs (less than 5); and metalling crest embankments.  
 
5.  The drainage system components includes cleaning of existing primary, secondary, and 
tertiary drains; and repair, rehabilitation, excavation, construction and lining of 100-150 km of 
drains and culverts. All structures comprising the drainage system will be designed to resist all 
forces and loads to which they will be subjected. Auxiliary elements will include silt traps, trash 
racks, weep holes, and plot drains. 
 
6.  Municipal  engineering  works  comprise  a  solid  waste  management  subcomponent, 
installation of sanitary latrines and slum improvement. Solid waste management will involve 
establishing sanitary landfill sites in eight towns, with provision for lining to protect impervious 
soils and groundwater and leachate collection and treatment ponds. This subcomponent will 
also provide for  pilot composting facilities (10 or 2 initially), demolition and disposal of 1,300 
dustheaps,  solid  waste  transfer  stations,  mechanical  sweeping  equipment,  strainers  for 
collecting of solid waste from drains, and transport facilities (rickshaws, pushcarts, garbage 
trucks, and bulldozers). The sanitation improvement subcomponent will provide 13,200 sanitary 
latrines  and  22  public  toilets.  The  slum  improvement  subcomponent  will  supply  basic 
infrastructure of sanitation, drainage, footpaths, water supply, and lighting.

C.   Description of the Environment 
 
7.  The STIFPP II is within the Asiatic monsoon region in Bangladesh. The area is humid 
tropical with prolonged monsoons for 4-5 months of the year and consequent intermittent 
flooding from May to October in large parts of the country. Elevations of the secondary towns 
generally vary from 5.5 meters (m) to 16.5 m above sea level. Both urban and rural areas 
surrounding the nine towns are generally subject to moderate to high flooding risk from the 
adjacent rivers, and internal runoff from intense or prolonged storm events.  The current 
drainage systems of these towns consist of small, ad hoc drainage ditches that were able to 
direct water to low-lying areas, ponds, khals (water channels), or rivers.  With the increase in 
population and building density, paved areas, and reduced green space, urban runoff discharge 
has increased considerably, often rendering existing drainage systems inadequate.  While the 
official 2001 population figures for the nine towns total 1.16 million, there are significant and 
unaccounted  for  poorer  income  groups,  notably  recently  settled  dwellers  who  are  most 
vulnerable to the impacts of flooding and inadequate drainage. 
 
8.  Surface waters in rivers, khals, and canals are unsuitable for drinking, but treatment can 
be easily provided. Groundwater in many areas of Bangladesh is often contaminated with 
naturally occurring arsenic and heavy metals; therefore, testing is essential. In all nine cities, 
ecological resources including fisheries and scarce natural forests, are declining due to large 
population pressures.. Crops cultivated in the surrounding lowland areas around the towns 
include rice, other  grains, and vegetables.  
 
D.   Forecasting Environmental Impacts and Mitigation Measures 
 
1.  Location 
 
9.  The proposed schemes are in nine towns located on the banks of powerful rivers. The 
towns are subject to regular internal and external floods. Earthquakes have been reported in the 
area; however, their magnitude over the  past 100 years was below 4 on the Richter scale. 
Environmental  risks  associated  with  structural  failure  will  be  prevented  through  the  strict 
implementation of Bangladesh’s Building Rules.  
 
10.  Project construction will require total land acquisition of 47.26 hectares (ha) for drainage 
and  flood  control  works,  which  affect  1,835  households.  A  comprehensive  compensation 
program has been produced in conjunction with an entitlement matrix to ensure that involuntary 
resettlement addresses compensation to replace lost assets, livelihood and income, assistance 
in relocation sites for appropriate facilities and services, and assistance in rehabilitation to 
achieve the same level of well-being. 
 
11.  Project implementation will result in the conversion of small amounts of rural agricultural 
land, with associated loss of trees and crops, and reduced fishponds for construction of flood 
protection structures, drainage system and landfill sites. The constructor will optimize the 
engineering design ensure that environmental impacts to the ecosystem are minimized.  
 
12.  Locations of landfill and solid waste transfer stations need in some cases to be finalized 
and future design should address associated complexities. Future selection should ensure that 
suitable sites will have minimal exposure to flooding; be located away from populated areas, 
near to a clay source or located on clays; have minimal resettlement requirements; and have a 
location  with  minimal  local  nuisance  hazards.  An  environmental  assessment  and  review

2.  Design 
 
13.  The  riverbank  will  have  significant  positive  impacts  by  protecting  the  productive 
agricultural land and homestead from progressive river erosion, that would result in associated 
displacement of households. However, active structures (groynes, spurs, guide bunds) and 
passive structures (bank protection structures, revetments) built on the riverbank will also cause 
morphological impacts, affecting the river flow and, to a certain extent, shaping the riverbed and 
the river course. Bank protection structures planned for the project are passive structures. 
These should be well-aligned with the direction of the flow to minimize bank erosion. River 
training in the form of active structures is, however, also part of the project. As a result, erosion 
upstream and downstream from the selected towns may occur. The aim to minimize erosion at 
upstream  and  downstream  locations  will  ultimately  affect  a  number  of  individuals  and 
vegetation. Flood modeling will be undertaken as part of engineering design. River training 
works will also have a small impact on aquatic organisms. 
 
14.  Interference of drainage facilities with other utilities is possible during construction of 
new drains. The situation will be mitigated through utility mapping and keeping minimal distance 
locations. Overflow and bypassing hazards may occur in areas serving large populations. For 
this purpose appropriate sizing and material selection will be essential. The cost estimate will 
have a budget provision for relocating and restoring or replacing damaged utilities to minimize 
the negative impact.   
 
15.  Appropriate waste segregation is essential to ensure a good operating a sanitary landfill 
site and successful composting facilities. The Project will provide equipment for segregating 
waste  during  collection,  to  be  further  confirmed  in  waste  transfer  centers.  In  addition,  a 
comprehensive solid waste management plan will be developed for each of the nine towns 
before loan disbursement starts. Leachate may contaminate soil and groundwater if no proper 
leachate collection system is provided. To prevent the problem, all landfill sites will be sanitary. 
The design should incorporate (i) waste segregation and recycling with the solid waste disposal 
system to maximize the service life of the landfill; (ii) a proper sanitary lining, preferably of clay 
or geosynthetic fabric; (iii) a system to properly collect and treat leachate; and (iv) the design of 
a collection system for landfill gases. Equipment should be provided for waste segregation 
during  collection  and  in  waste  transfer  centers.  When  finalized  site  selection  is,  a  full 
consultation process with affected people will be conducted during the detailed design stage.  
Endorsement from ADB will be sought before initiating construction activities. 
 
16.  Sanitation facilities to be provided under this Project will include only sanitary pit latrines 
for households that do not have the financial resources to install them, and public toilets. Where

3.  Construction Impacts on Physical Environment 
 
17.  During construction, a large amount of sand will have to be transported to the sites. 
Storage of sand and sand-filled geo-bags at the project site may generate dust. Impacts during 
transport and storage of sand will be minimized by covering the sand or by keeping the surface 
wet. If sand is to be transported by boat, boatowners will be required to keep their engines 
properly maintained to reduce air pollution from exhausts and oil spills in the water courses. 
Similar practices will be observed for land transportation. 
 
18.  Site construction activities such as digging of drains or landfill site landscaping will also 
generate dust, noise, vibration that will affect both workers on-site and the nearby population. 
Soil erosion may result from land preparation activities. Proposed mitigating measures include 
use of dust suppression techniques such as water sprays, covered wagons and skips; work 
within agreed-upon hours; plants and equipment with low operating noise levels; and limiting 
excavation and land leveling works during the rainy season. 
 
19.  Extensive sand mining or sand from land immediately adjacent to the riverbanks may 
cause substantial erosion in these areas. An alternative solution is sand dredging from river 
beds, since construction will take place over a period of 5 years and the dredged volume is 
considered small with respect to the estimated annual bed load transport. Establishment of 
working areas and storage of sand and sand-filled geo-bags at the project site may damage 
local vegetation and degrade the topsoil, affecting its productivity. Removing the topsoil from the 
storage site and returning it on completion of construction may be appropriate; however, sand 
storage site selecting in areas with no topsoil (sandy areas) would be more appropriate.  
 
4.  Construction Impacts on Ecosystems 
 
20.  During construction, sediments may reach the aquatic habitat due to sand mining, 
transport, storing, filling of sandbags, and dumping. Slope preparation that may be necessary at 
some  stretches  would  spread  sediments.  However,  the  expected  increase  in  sediment 
concentration is not considered higher than that generated at present by river erosion and may 
be considered minor. 
 
21.  The Project will not encroach into terrestrial habitats of significance. On completion, 
however, the embankment in some areas may prevent some terrestrial fauna from coming to 
the river to drink. Given the urban nature of many of the sites, the impact on terrestrial 
ecosystems is expected to be minimal. During construction, noise may disturb the scarce 
wildlife and birds in the vicinity. Measures undertaken to minimize impacts to the surrounding 
population will also be of benefit to the ecosystems.

volume will be enforced through a sound traffic management plan promoting traffic flow and 
focusing on the highly populated areas or schools. Interaction with the public will be encouraged 
through continuous dialogue and information exchange, establishing a procedure for recording 
and dealing with complaints, and workers instruction. Good health and hygiene practices at 
work and reduced work accidents will be achieved by means of an occupational health and

6.  Operation 
 
23.  Intense floods can last for 2 months of the year, preventing the opening of gates and 
sluices  and  therefore  discharge  of  drains  into  the  watercourses.  The  water  then  remains 
stagnant and concentrates in lower areas of the town, possibly creating an insect-breeding 
habitat. While internal hydrological studies were conducted to address some of the issues 
during  the  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  (PPTA),  a  sanitation  and  wastewater 
treatment management plan will be formulated for each of the nine towns to suggest appropriate 
sanitation measures. 
 
24.  As part of the mitigating measures implemented in the solid waste management center, 
regular pest (rodents and insects) treatment will be carried out. Moreover, an OHSP ensuring 
the safety and good health of the operators in those centers will be formulated and endorsed 
before  starting operation.   
 
25.  The  proposed  landfill  is  anticipated  to  produce  significant  amounts  of  gases,  e.g. 
methane and carbon dioxide. In addition, gases like, hydrogen sulfide, carbon monoxide, and 
ammonia may be formed in small quantities from decomposing solid waste. These are odorous 
gases and may create nuisance and health hazards to nearby communities if not controlled. In 
addition,  they  may  have  some  negative  effect  on  the  vegetation  of  the  area.  Mitigating 
measures proposed to minimize the negative impacts include provision of proper soil cover, 
buffer zone, planting, and a proper gas control system. The option to reuse methane as biogas 
for power production may also be considered at the detailed design stage. 
   
26.  It is envisaged that traffic loads in the area approaching the landfill site may increase 
due to the movement of transfer vehicles, and their affect the community and cause nuisance 
and health risks. Mitigating measures will include transport of waste during times of light traffic 
to minimize gas emissions in busy areas, provision of a traffic management plan and close 
coordination between municipalities and traffic police personnel for smooth execution. 
 
27.  The presence of silt and solid waste in drains may obstruct the flow, resulting in overflow 
or flooding, and further environmental pollution in areas along the drains. Provision must be 
made for cleaning and desilting by the municipalities. The design must consider accessibility of 
the drains. 
 
28.  Operation and regular maintenance of both latrines and toilets and sanitary landfill site 
are  essential  to  achieve  the  objectives  of  environmental  improvement.  This  issue  will  be 
addressed  in  detail  in  the  solid  waste  management  plan  and  sanitation  and  wastewater 
management plan to be formulated before loan effectiveness for each of the nine secondary 
towns. Impacts to be addressed will include safety of health workers and the neighborhood, pest 
prevention, collection and disposal of treated leachate, waste segregation, reuse and recycling, 
public awareness and required training, and operation linkages with the private sector for 
fertilizer conversion.

E.   Environmental Monitoring Plan and Institutional Requirements  
 
30.  Technical  and  institutional  mitigating  measures  will  be  incorporated  in  the  detailed 
design of the Project. Measures of a planning, functional, institutional and procedural character 
have to be included in the site selection criteria, in the tender documents, and in the OHSP and 
the traffic plan. Mitigating measures related to the construction works will be stated in the 
contract with the contractor. The project management unit (PMU), LGED, and Bangladesh 
Water Development Board (BWDB), and project implementation units (PIUs) in the project 
towns  will  be  responsible  for  monitoring  and  enforcement  during  construction.  During  the 
operational  phase,  the  communities  undertaking  solid  waste  management  activities,  and 
municipal  authorities  aided  by  BWDB  and  LGED  will  be  responsible  for  implementing 
environmental measures in the sector of water and municipal engineering, respectively.  The 
executing  agency  will  obtain  relevant  environmental  clearances  from  the  Department  of 
Environment before implementing of any civil works activities. The Department of Environment 
will  be  responsible  for  overseeing  overall  environmental  compliance  and  environmental 
monitoring. During its review missions, ADB will also assess environmental compliance in the 
different towns. 
 
F.   Public Consultation and Disclosure  
 
31.  Formal and informal consultation exercises were undertaken during preparation of the 
project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA). Municipal and government officials were also 
interviewed and their views solicited regarding STIFPP II goals and objectives. A total of 57 
meetings and formal and informal consultations were carried out in the nine towns of concerned. 
Meetings were held with affected groups, municipal authorities, and various sectors of society 
within  the  vicinity  of  the  project  sites.  Other  groups  consulted  included  villagers,  town 
inhabitants, and nongovernment organizations (NGOs). Main issues of interest included (i) the 
need for an efficient solid waste management system, (ii) access to safe drinking water, (iii) 
need  for  flood  protection  and  flood  embankments,  and  (iv)  desire  for  an  environmental 
awareness campaign. In addition, in agreement with ADB’s information disclosure requirements, 
this summary IEE will be available worldwide through the depository library system and the ADB 
web site. 
 
G.   Findings and Recommendations  
 
32.  Environmental  screening  processes  were  carried  out  in  nine  cities.  Positive 
environmental impacts result from protecting the towns against recurrent internal and external 
floods, improving overall internal drainage, managing solid waste, and improving sanitation.  
Mitigating measures and an environmental monitoring plan have been formulated to minimize 
negative environmental impacts.  
 
H.   Conclusions 
 
33.  The proposed Project will significantly improve the overall environmental quality of the 
participating secondary towns. The Project will not have significant environmental impacts and 
classification B is appropriate. Therefore an environmental impact assessment is not deemed 
necessary.
